repnme.cdata!:
Republic of Yemen - Land and Water
            Conservation, Taiz Water Supply Pilot, and Sana'a Water
            Supply and Sanitation Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The report rates the three projects as
            such: The Land and Water Conservation Project had a
            satisfactory outcome, is likely to be sustainable, has a
            modest institutional development impact, and satisfactory
            performances by both the Borrower and the Bank. The Taiz
            Water Supply Pilot Project had an unsatisfactory outcome, is
            unlikely to be sustainable, has a modest institutional
            development impact, and unsatisfactory performances by both
            the Borrower and the Bank. The Sana'a Water Supply and
            Sanitation Project had a moderately satisfactory outcome, is
            unlikely to be sustainable, has a high institutional
            development impact, unsatisfactory performance by the Bank,
            and satisfactory performance by the Borrower. The report
            cites four key lessons for success, which were not
            emphasized enough to affect the outcomes in two of these
            three projects: 1) identifying and tackling the dominant
            issue-here, the depletion of Yemen's water resources;
            2) having a comprehensive strategy based on sector analysis
            and a program approach; 3) having cross-sector planning and
            coordination among the rural, urban, and other water
            water-using sectors; and 4) developing rural-urban water markets.

repnme.cdata!: Yemen - Taiz Water Supply Pilot Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Taiz Water Supply
            Pilot Project is rated as unsatisfactory, sustainability as
            unlikely, institutional development impact as negligible,
            Bank performance as satisfactory, and borrower performance
            as satisfactory. The key lessons learned from this project
            include: Do not combine a pilot approach with an emergency
            project. In an emergency project, time is scarce.
            Established, low-risk approaches should be used to deliver
            results quickly. In a pilot project, new approaches should
            be tested, the risk of failure should be deliberately taken,
            and time should be allowed for careful monitoring and
            evaluation. All risks should be assessed in a comprehensive
            and realistic manner. At preparation and supervision, staff
            with all specialties should be included. Project objectives
            not reflecting reality should be revised and changes should
            be formalized in the credit agreement. Even at the cost of
            being limited to a more narrowly focused sectoral approach,
            avoid three different implementing agencies and Project
            Management Units. It is essential to have a good
            understanding of the water resource, the shape of the
            aquifers and the relation between them, and the
            relationships between surface and groundwater resources.
            There is a need to spell out the "hydraulic goal"
            of the project. There is a need for upfront stakeholder
            analysis which should be used as the basis to select upfront
            representative stakeholder institutions.

repnme.cdata!: Republic of Yemen - Taiz Water Supply Pilot Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Taiz Water Supply Pilot
            Project's main objectives are to mitigate the immediate
            water shortage in the city of Taiz and identify new water
            sources to avert a sustained water shortage. The project
            also aims at developing and testing an institutional
            framework for decentralized water resource management
            through local community participation and promoting private
            sector participation in the management of water and
            wastewater utility services. The project consists of three
            components: a) well drilling and conveyance to Taiz; b) a
            compensation package for people in the Habir area who will
            give up water for Taiz, consisting of rural water supply
            schemes that include a pilot program of activities targeted
            at women; two demonstration irrigation schemes including
            wells, piping and technical assistance; school rooms; and
            studies for an aquifer recharge dike in Habir area; and c)
            studies of surface and ground water sources for urban and
            rural development; technical assistance for the preparation
            of a second phase project for Taiz city and Al Qaidah town;
            and preparation of a management contract for Taiz National
            Water and Sanitation Authority branch for implementation in
            the second phase project.
